item.title: Bull vs bear: Can GST reform bring the Indian stock market out of the league of worst performers in global markets?

review.headline_rewrite: Bull vs bear: Can GST reform bring the Indian stock market out of the league of worst performers in global markets?
bullets: However, the spike in the key benchmark indices was short-lived as profit-booking triggered in the second half, paring most of the morning gains.
The BSE Sensex has shed 0.58% in one year, and the 30-stock index has gained 2.81% YTD.
Speaking on the GST reforms' impact on the Indian stock market, Avinash Gorakshkar, a SEBI-registered fundamental analyst, said, "GST reforms are a right step
As new GST taxes are being implemented from 22 September 2025, their impact on the Q2FY26 results will be minimal.

item.title: Is the Indian stock market open or closed on Monday after the declaration of a public holiday in Mumbai?

review.headline_rewrite: Is the Indian stock market open or closed on Monday after the declaration of a public holiday in Mumbai?
bullets: To avoid confusion, investors and stock market observers are advised to look at the stock market holidays 2025 list on the official BSE website
This means NSE and BSE will remain open on Monday.
In other words, trading activities at the NSE and the BSE will resume as usual after the regular weekend holidays.

item.title: India navigating a shifting landscape: The impact of US tariffs on the global fertiliser market

review.headline_rewrite: India navigating a shifting landscape: The impact of US tariffs on the global fertiliser market
bullets: The global fertiliser sector confronts unprecedented disruption as recent US trade policy modifications fundamentally reshape international supply networks.

Escalating geopolitical tensions compound these challenges, generating widespread uncertainty across agricultural markets and affecting farming communities worldwide through strained distribution channels.
How US tariffs are shaking up fertiliser markets On July 31, President Trump signed an executive order that’s already causing ripple effects across global
When fertiliser prices spike globally, India’s procurement expenses will climb, putting immense pressure on farmers which eventually will hurt their profits, raise food costs
